title: 107_s550
content: The Act titled "Indian and Alaska Native Foster Care and Adoption Services Amendments of 2001" allows Indian tribes to receive federal funds for foster care and adoption assistance. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act. This includes Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program under specific sections, but have a cooperative agreement with a State or submit arrangements to the Secretary. Children in tribal custody can receive foster care funding under the Social Security Act if they are part of an Indian tribe or intertribal consortium that does not operate a program under certain sections but has a cooperative agreement with a State or submits arrangements to the Secretary. Children in tribal custody can receive foster care funding under the Social Security Act if they are part of an Indian tribe or intertribal consortium that does not operate a program under certain sections but has a cooperative agreement with a State or submits arrangements to the Secretary. Programs operated by Indian tribal organizations are covered under SEC. 479B. The Social Security Act allows Indian tribes to operate foster care programs similar to states, with modifications to plan requirements such as identifying service areas and approving foster homes. Indian tribes can identify service areas and approve foster homes for their foster care programs, ensuring child safety and accountability. The federal share is determined based on per capita income. The federal share for Indian tribes in foster care programs is determined based on per capita income. When determining the Federal medical assistance percentage for an Indian tribe, the per capita income calculation is based on the service population defined in the tribe's plan. The tribe can also submit additional information to the Secretary. The Secretary will determine the per capita income of an Indian tribe based on the tribe's service population as defined in its plan. The tribe can also provide additional information for consideration before the calculation is made. Administrative expenditures proportions will be determined by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary will consider the per capita income of the Indian tribe before making calculations. Administrative expenditures proportions for Indian tribes will be determined by the Secretary through regulations, ensuring they receive a proportion not less than that specified for a State. Indian tribes can use Federal or State funds to match payments. An Indian tribe can use Federal or State funds to match payments under section 474, ensuring they receive a proportion not less than that specified for a State. The Secretary may modify requirements under this part upon request from an Indian tribe. An Indian tribe may request modifications to requirements under this part to benefit the safety of children they serve. Participating Indian tribes in an intertribal consortium can submit a single plan that meets the necessary criteria. The modification of requirements can benefit the safety of children served by Indian tribes. Participating tribes in an intertribal consortium can submit a single plan. Indian tribes or consortiums can enter into cooperative agreements with states for fund administration. Cooperative agreements between Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums and states for fund administration are valid and enforceable. Existing agreements remain in effect unless revoked or modified according to their terms. Regulations must be established within one year. The Secretary must establish regulations within one year in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations to carry out valid cooperative agreements between tribes, states, or intertribal consortiums for fund administration.
